fossa so let's get right into it
the cubital fossa is this little
triangular depression that you see right
here in the region between the two
forearm bones so you have the forearm
bones the radius and the ulna the radius
of course is going to be lateral and the
ulna is going to be medial so just
imagine the two bones that are under
here the radius and the ulna and right
in between those two right as you go
from the arm to the forearm region
you're gonna get a triangular depression
let me actually zoom in a little more
there we go that's good and you can
actually feel this if you just took you
your fingers right now and put them
between your arm and your forearm you'll
feel this little depression that I am
going to outline right now so right here
you see this little triangular
depression it shapes like a triangle
with the base that's superior so this is
your superior base and then of course
you have the other two sides of the
triangle so first I want to talk about
what those boundaries are first the the
base is going to be this line that you
see right here now there isn't any
particular structure that outlines that
B so that's kind of like a
imaginary line between the two
epicondyles all right so we have the
lateral epicondyle here which is this
part on the lateral side when you look
at the structure of the humerus you'll
see we have that lateral epicondyle and
of course we have our medial epicondyle
which is is the larger of the two
epicondyle so I should have drawn that
as a bigger bulge so we have the medial
epicondyle and the lateral epicondyle
and there's an imaginary line that we're
imagining right between those two
structures that's the base of the
triangle and then of course the lateral
border of that triangle is going to be
this muscle right here
that's your brachial radialis muscle and
then the medial border that's going to
be this muscle right here the pronator
teres muscle and that is going to give
you your entire triangle from the base
being that imaginary line between the
two epicondyles then we have our lateral
boundary which is made up of the
brachial radialis muscle and the medial
boundary is outlined by that pronator
teres muscle then of course we have to
have a roof and a floor let's take the
floor first because we can see that
right here in in order to see the floor
I'm actually going to hide your biceps
muscles and then here you can see this
brachialis muscle which is gonna be
forming the floor of that triangle so
that's the floor of the little
depression that you have there and then
of course we can't have a floor without
having a roof that just that's just not
as cool so let's add our roof and the
roof will be formed by a number of
structures this four structure that you
see here is the bicep node bicipital
aponeurosis
bicipital aponeurosis you have the
biceps that are inserting on that bicep
well they're using the bicipital
aponeurosis which is a flattish tendon
that it serves as part of the insertion
of the biceps muscle the biceps brachii
so that's the first part of the roof the
second part has to do with a vein that's
going through that cubital fossa and
that is your medial cubital vein that
vein that i have highlighted right there
and then the third part or the third
aspect would be two nerves that we have
coming through and I'm just gonna kind
of draw them in but you have a medial
and a lateral cutaneous nerve of the
forearm the medial and lateral cutaneous
nerves of the forearm that makes up also
part of the roof of that cubital fossa
so in review let's look at all of that
again when it comes to the boundaries we
have our base which is formed by that
imaginary line between the lateral and
medial epicondyle you have your lateral
boundary which is formed by your
brachioradialis muscle you have your
medial boundary and that is formed by
the pronator teres muscle then you have
the floor
I'm not gonna show that right now but
the floor is made up of the brachialis
muscle and the roof we have our three
structures the bicipital aponeurosis the
medial median cubital vein and then the
two nerves the lateral and the medial
cutaneous nerves of the forearm so
